questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a patient presenting with diarrhea, fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and lymphadenopathy, whose lymph node biopsy reveals nontuberculous mycobacteria, and has a CD4 count of 48/mm³?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient, who is severely immunocompromised (CD4 <50/mm³), is presenting with systemic symptoms including fever, diarrhoea, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy.
  • A lymph node biopsy revealing nontuberculous mycobacteria is highly suggestive of disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • The recommended treatment for MAC includes a macrolide (either clarithromycin or azithromycin) combined with ethambutol.
  • Rifabutin may be added in advanced or refractory cases, but is not the first-line component.
  • MAC is most common in AIDS patients with a CD4 count <50/mm³.
  • Common symptoms include fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and lymphadenopathy.
  • Laboratory diagnosis is confirmed via blood or lymph node culture.
  • Azithromycin is no longer routinely used for prophylaxis due to ART-related immune reconstitution.

Explanation of other options:

Macrolide + Rifampin (Option A): Rifampin is used in the treatment of tuberculosis and some atypical mycobacteria, but is not preferred in MAC due to its less synergistic activity and potential for drug interactions.

Azithromycin (Option B): Monotherapy is ineffective for active MAC disease. Azithromycin was formerly used for prophylaxis.

Clarithromycin (Option D): Correct drug class, but monotherapy is inadequate. Needs to be combined with ethambutol for optimal efficacy and prevention of resistance.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, chronic cough, shortness of breath, night sweats, hemoptysis and weight loss for 15 days. She was diagnosed with HIV 7 years ago. Her CD cell count is 50/µL. Her chest X-ray is given below. The doctor suspects a MAC infection in the patient. According to the Runyon classification, which group does MAC belong to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is immunocompromised (CD4 <50/μL) and presents with systemic symptoms typical of disseminated MAC
  • According to the Runyon classification, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) falls under Group III: Nonphotochromogens.
  • These organisms produce no pigment regardless of light exposure and grow slowly (more than 7 days) at 37°C. This classification helps differentiate nontuberculous mycobacteria based on pigment production and growth rate.
  • Runyon's classification divides non-tuberculous mycobacteria based on pigment production and rate of growth.

Explanation of other options:

Photochromogens (Option A): Produce pigment only when exposed to light. MAC does not show this feature.

Scotochromogens (Option B): Produce pigment in both light and dark. MAC is not included in this group.

Rapid growers (Option D): Grow in less than 7 days. MAC is a slow grower and thus not classified here.

questions.text: An aquarium owner presents with the following lesions on his hand after a minor trauma. You are told that similar lesions are produced by a subcutaneous infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Which photochromogen is implicated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image and clinical history are consistent with fish tank/swimming pool granuloma, a cutaneous infection often seen in individuals who work with aquariums.
  • The organism responsible is Mycobacterium marinum, a photochromogen belonging to Runyon Group I, known to cause nodular lesions along lymphatics, resembling Sporothrix schenckii infection (sporotrichoid spread).
  • This organism forms yellow-orange pigment only after exposure to light and takes more than 7 days to grow, consistent with the definition of a photochromogen.

Explanation of other options:

M.scrofulaceum (Option A): A scotochromogen (Runyon Group II); causes cervical lymphadenitis in children.

M.xenopi (Option B): A nonphotochromogen (Runyon Group III); associated with pulmonary infections, particularly in Europe.

MAC (Option C): Includes M. avium and M. intracellulare; classified as nonphotochromogens (Runyon Group III), not linked to skin lesions.

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the swelling

questions.text: A 10 year old child presented with an anterior neck swelling with a discharge. The mother said that the child was having fever for 14 days, more in the evenings than in mornings, accompanied by cough and night sweats. Upon asking for vaccination history, she said that she didn't believe in 'jabbing her baby' with needles. On examining the swelling, it was normal to touch, non-mobile with no local changes. The patient also happens to belong to a low socio-economic strata. Given the child's history, which of the investigations will you perform next, according to the RNTCP guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes a case of tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis, the most common form of extrapulmonary TB in children.
  • Given the child's constitutional symptoms, low socioeconomic status, and unvaccinated background, TB is the most likely diagnosis.
  • As per the RNTCP (NTEP) diagnostic algorithm, CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) is the preferred first-line diagnostic tool for suspected TB lymphadenitis in children due to its rapid turnaround, high sensitivity, and ability to detect rifampicin resistance.

The latest RNTCP guidelines are as follows-

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculin sensitivity testing (Option A): Helpful in supportive diagnosis, but not a standalone or confirmatory test per guidelines.

Incision and drainage (Option B): Not recommended in suspected tuberculous lymphadenitis due to the risk of sinus formation and poor healing.

Directly starting DOTS (Option C): Treatment should follow microbiological confirmation, where feasible, as per NTEP protocol.

questions.text:
You are performing the ZN staining for your microbiology practicals. You notice that the decolourizer is 5% sulphuric acid. Which of the following will stain acid fast positive with this concentration of sulphuric acid?
i. M.leprae
ii. MAC
iii. Legionella
iv. M.tuberculosis
v. Oocyst of cryptosporidium
vi. Oocyst of tenia
vii. Actinomyces
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This question refers to modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining, in which 5% sulfuric acid is used as the decolouriser instead of 20%.
  • This reduced concentration is used specifically for weakly acid-fast organisms like M. leprae. Strongly acid-fast organisms like M. tuberculosis also retain carbol fuchsin with 5% acid.
  • However, organisms like Cryptosporidium, Taenia, Actinomyces, and Legionella are either not acid-fast or require alternate techniques (e.g., Kinyoun's stain for Cryptosporidium using 1% H2SO4).

choices.text: Prescribe ATT and advise him to begin with ART 8 weeks later
Prescribe ART and advise him to begin with ATT 8 weeks later
ATT is not recommended in HIV AIDS

questions.text: Rajesh is a 32 year old man who has been worried about his weight loss. He was 70kgs 6 months ago and currently weighs 58kg. He has also been experiencing bouts of diarrhea, episodes of fever in the evening and generalized fatigue. Upon repeated questioning he revealed having illicit relations and unprotected intercourse with his partner. Unfortunately, he tested positive for both HIV AIDS and TB. You explain to him that he will have to undergo treatment for both. He asks you if he can just take his medications together . What will you counsel?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In patients with HIV-TB co-infection, initiating ATT first and ART after a short delay (usually 2–8 weeks) is recommended to reduce the risk of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS), especially in patients with advanced immunosuppression (CD4 <50 cells/μL).
  • Starting both simultaneously increases the risk of toxicity, drug-drug interactions, and IRIS.
  • Currently, a 2-month initial intensive phase of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, followed by 4 months of continuation phase of isoniazid and rifampin, is considered the standard treatment of drug-susceptible TB.
  • Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI)-based ART remains a first-line regimen for HIV-infected patients with TB in resource-limited settings.
  • Although a standard dose of both efavirenz and nevirapine can be used, efavirenz is preferred because of more favourable treatment outcomes.
  • In the settings where raltegravir is accessible, doubling the dose to 800mg twice daily is recommended.
  • Adverse reactions to either antituberculous or antiretroviral drugs, as well as immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome, are common in patients receiving integrated therapy. Early recognition and appropriate management of these consequences can reinforce the successful integrated therapy in HIV-infected patients with TB.

Explanation of other options:

Prescribe ART and ATT together (Option A): Starting ART and ATT together may increase the risk of drug toxicity and IRIS, especially with advanced immunosuppression.

Prescribe ART and advise him to begin with ATT 8 weeks later (Option C): ART should not precede ATT in active TB. Risk of worsening TB and resistance.

ATT is not recommended in HIV AIDS (Option D): ATT is essential and strongly recommended in HIV-TB co-infection. Not giving it is against national guidelines.

questions.text: You see the following packet in a Dermatology OPD being prescribed to patients with certain types of hypopigmented skin lesions and hypoanesthesia. However, you are confused about the duration for which the regimen is to be given to the patient. Your senior advises you to first classify the disease as paucibacillary or multibacillary. You consider the skin and nerve involvement and classify it as a multibacillary case. Which immunity is defective in patients developing this type of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cell-mediated immunity is the major host defence mechanism against Mycobacterium leprae. In lepromatous leprosy, which is typically seen in multibacillary cases, there is a profound defect in cell-mediated immunity (CMI).
  • This immunologic deficiency allows leprae to multiply unimpeded in the skin and peripheral nerves, resulting in multiple lesions and high bacterial load.
  • In contrast, tuberculoid leprosy (paucibacillary) shows a strong CMI and fewer lesions with low or undetectable bacilli.
  • Numerous lesions, bilateral nerve involvement, and positive skin smears characterise multibacillary leprosy.
  • CMI is crucial for the containment of M. leprae. Its absence results in disseminated disease.
  • WHO classification uses skin lesion count and slit-skin smear positivity for classifying cases.
  • A defective Th1-type response in multibacillary cases is replaced by a predominant Th2-type response, which is ineffective in clearing intracellular pathogens like M. leprae.
  • Multibacillary leprosy = High bacillary load + negative lepromin test + defective CMI
  • MDT (multidrug therapy) regimen for multibacillary cases is longer (12 months)
  • Diagnosis includes clinical, histopathologic, and bacteriologic parameters.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a numb patch on his arm and a few small nodules on his face. He reports a history of skin changes over the past several months, including lighter-coloured patches that are less sensitive to touch. On examination, you notice thickened peripheral nerves. Which strain has been used for this disease vaccine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient with the above clinical features is likely to be diagnosed with leprosy.

  • The killed Mycobacterium indicus pranii vaccine for leprosy was developed in India in 2018.
  • MIP is a killed, non-pathogenic mycobacterium strain developed in India and used as an immunotherapeutic vaccine for leprosy.
  • It enhances the immune response against Mycobacterium leprae by boosting cell-mediated immunity.
  • Trials have shown that when given to close contacts, it can reduce leprosy incidence by about 60% over 3 years.
  • MIP boosts Th1 immune response against leprae.
  • BCG is still used in endemic countries like India, with variable efficacy.
  • MIP is part of India's NLEP (National Leprosy Eradication Programme) strategy.

questions.text: While performing the following staining for a patient presenting with leonine facies, you happen to count both live and dead bacteria per oil immersion field. Which index will you be measuring?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bacteriological index (BI): It is based on the total number of bacilli (live and dead) seen per oil immersion field.
  • The bacteriological index (BI) is calculated by totalling the number of pluses scored in all the smears and dividing by the number of smears examined.
  • Morphological index (MI): It is expressed as the percentage of uniformly stained bacilli out of the total number of bacilli counted. (Option C ruled out)
  • MI is a better marker to monitor the treatment response.
  • Following clinical improvement by treatment, the MI should fall, whereas the BI may remain the same.
  • SFG percentage (solid, fragmented granular rod percentage): Since the percentage of solid, fragmented granular rods is recorded separately, this method gives a better picture of the bacterial morphology and is a more sensitive indicator of monitoring the treatment response than MI. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which class of leprosy, according to the Ridley-Jopling classification, is more likely to develop an acute exacerbation of leprosy wherein there is an inflammation of existing lesions and is a delayed type hypersensitivity to lepra antigens?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ridley-Jopling Classification and Type I Lepra Reaction: Lepra reactions are acute inflammatory episodes occurring during the course of leprosy.
  • Type I lepra reaction (also called reversal reaction) is a delayed-type hypersensitivity (Type IV) immune response seen in borderline forms of leprosy.
  • Among them, Borderline Borderline (BB) is the immunologically most unstable form and is most prone to reversal reactions.
  • Patients with BB leprosy exhibit an unstable cell-mediated immune response that can shift toward either pole (TT or LL), leading to frequent acute exacerbations.
  • TT (Tuberculoid): Stable CMI, less likely to develop Type I reaction
  • LL (Lepromatous): No DTH; develops Type II reactions (ENL)
  • BB: Unstable immunity → frequent DTH → Type I reaction
  • Type I reaction may lead to nerve damage if untreated

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with hypopigmented skin lesions and peripheral neuropathy. A skin biopsy is performed, and histopathological examination reveals a dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis, with the presence of foamy macrophages and acid-fast bacilli. In this condition which nerve would never be involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient with hypopigmented skin lesions and peripheral neuropathy with HP showing dense lymphocytic infiltrates is suggestive of leprosy.
  • The optic nerve is never involved in Leprosy.
  • The most commonly involved nerve is the ulnar, followed by post auricular. (Option C)
  • While peripheral nerves are commonly affected, the optic nerve is spared from the disease.
  • Since lepra bacilli grow in cooler areas, they invade cutaneous nerves first; hence, thermal sensations are lost earlier.
  • Neural involvement can manifest itself as enlargement of the superficial nerves, such as the great auricular, ulnar, median, radial cutaneous, superficial peroneal, sural, and posterior tibial (Option A), which are clinically palpable against the corresponding bony prominences when thickened; associated with tenderness, in case of coexistent neuritis.
  • Lateral popliteal nerve (Option D) is commonly affected due to its superficial course.
  • Sensory impairment over the skin lesions is assessed by loss of sensation of temperature, touch, or pain. Thirty per cent of the sensory nerve fibres need to be affected by the lepra bacilli before sensory deficit becomes clinically manifest.
  • Nerve damage in leprosy may present itself as silent neuropathy without overt signs and symptoms or as clinically manifest disease, which may present as weakness, atrophy or contracture. Glove and stocking pattern of sensory impairment results from damage to the type C fibres that carry heat and cold discrimination, which is the earliest sensation lost during the disease.
  • Touch sensation is lost, subsequently followed by that of pain. Patients may complain of anhidrosis if there is associated sympathetic nerve involvement.

choices.text: Reduce duration of therapy to 4 months

questions.text: What would be the next step for a known patient of LL experiencing new painful lesions on his skin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anti-leprosy therapy (MDT) should not be stopped.
  • Instead, add systemic corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) to reduce inflammation and prevent nerve damage.
  • In recurrent or severe cases, thalidomide may be used, especially in males
  • This case describes a case of type-2 lepra reaction, which is a type-3 hypersensitivity to lepra antigens.
  • It is characterised by painful new crops of lesions, known as Lucio phenomena and may/may not occur during therapy.
  • Type 2 reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) occurs in the LL and BL types, usually a few months after the institution of chemotherapy.
  • Crops of tender, inflamed subcutaneous nodules appear, with fever, lymphadenopathy and arthralgia. This is an Arthus-type response to antigens released from dead lepra cells, which is characterised by neutrophil infiltration and IgG and complement deposition in the lesions.

Explanation for other options:

Stopping anti-leprosy therapy (Option A) is not advisable, as the patient is experiencing an exacerbation. Instead, we can manage the exacerbation with corticosteroids while continuing the anti-leprosy treatment to ensure the disease remains effectively treated.

Reduce duration of therapy to 4 months (Option C): Reducing the duration of therapy to 4 months is not advisable, as it could lead to incomplete treatment and allow the disease to persist in the patient.

Change rifampicin to rifabutin (Option D): This type 2 reaction is not an indication to change the medication, as drug resistance would be a more relevant reason for modifying the treatment.

questions.text: You see the following test being performed on a patient with multiple hypopigmented skin patches and foot drop. You are informed that the reading for this test is taken on 2 occasions. On the 1st reading taken at 48h, you notice an induration. What does it signify?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The test shown is the Lepromin test, which is a skin test using leprae antigens injected intradermally to assess host immune response. There are two types of responses:
  • Fernandez reaction (Early reaction: at 48 hours):
    • This is a Type IV hypersensitivity (delayed-type)
    • A positive reaction indicates prior exposure to leprae or a similar environmental mycobacterium.
    • It manifests as induration at the site within 48-72 hours.
  • Mitsuda reaction (Late response: at 21 days):
    • Reflects cell-mediated immunity (CMI).
    • Positive in tuberculoid forms, negative in lepromatous forms.
  • Therefore, a positive early response at 48 hours indicates previous sensitisation (i.e., past exposure), but does not confirm effective CMI on its own.

Explanation of other options:

Intact CMI (Option B): This is assessed by the Mitsuda reaction at 21 days, not by the Fernandez response at 48h.

Anaphylactic reaction (Option C): This is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction and does not involve induration at 48h.

Lepra reaction (Option D): Lepra reactions are immunologic complications during treatment, not diagnostic skin tests.

questions.text: Primary pulmonary TB is defined as the initial exogenous infection with tubercle bacilli. What is the name of the complex when the primary complex gets calcified?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ranke complex is the term used when the Ghon complex, which consists of a subpleural Ghon focus and involved hilar lymph nodes, undergoes fibrosis and calcification.
  • This transformation signifies a healed primary TB infection and is typically seen in individuals who successfully mounted a cell-mediated immune response.
  • In approximately 95% of immunocompetent individuals, the immune system contains the primary infection.
  • The remaining calcified lesions (Ranke complex) may be observed as radiopaque nodules in the mid-lung zones or hilar regions during chest imaging.
  • Ghon complex + calcification = Ranke complex.
  • Seen in healed cases with effective immune containment
  • Ranke complex is not a sign of active disease.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman presents to the Dermatology OPD with the following lesions on her face. The lesions enhanced after a glass slide was pressed on them. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above image represents Lupus vulgaris, the commonest dermatological manifestation of EPTB.
  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis. It presents as slowly enlarging, reddish-brown plaques, usually over the face or extremities. A key diagnostic feature is the "apple jelly" nodules seen on diascopy, a phenomenon caused by granulomatous tissue viewed through compressed dermal capillaries.
  • This form of TB arises due to hematogenous or contiguous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in a sensitised individual. Histologically, lupus vulgaris demonstrates epithelioid granulomas with Langhans giant cells, and caseation necrosis may be minimal or absent.

Explanation of other options:

Fish tank granuloma (Option A): Typically affects hands or elbows due to M. marinum exposure from water, not facial plaques with an apple jelly appearance.

Leonine facies (Option B): Seen in lepromatous leprosy, with nodular infiltration and bilateral facial thickening, not apple jelly on diascopy.

SLE (Option D): Presents with malar rash that is erythematous but non-granulomatous and not enhanced on diascopy.

questions.text: Which of the following is known as Johne's bacilli?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mycobacterium paratuberculosis is the organism known as Johne's bacillus, named after Heinrich Albert Johne, who first described the chronic enteritis it causes in ruminants.
  • This bacillus causes Johne's disease, a chronic granulomatous enterocolitis in cattle and sheep, and is notable for its slow growth, requiring mycobactin-supplemented media for cultivation.
  • While not a major human pathogen, M. paratuberculosis has been implicated as a possible factor in Crohn's disease, though this link remains controversial and unconfirmed.
  • Mycobacterium intracellulare (Option B) is known as Battey's bacilli
  • Mycobacterium leprae (Option C) is known as Hansen's bacilli

questions.text: By what mechanism does mycobacterium tuberculosis survive intracellularly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an obligate intracellular pathogen that survives inside macrophages by inhibiting phagolysosome fusion.
  • This immune evasion mechanism is crucial for its persistence in host tissues.
  • The organism avoids intracellular killing by blocking the normal maturation of the phagosome, preventing it from fusing with the lysosome.
  • This block is largely mediated by the bacterial cell wall component lipoarabinomannan (LAM), which interferes with the host's intracellular signalling, particularly by reducing Ca² flux and inhibiting the recruitment of vesicular proton ATPases, thus impairing acidification of the phagosome.

Explanation of other options:

Resistance to lysosomal enzymes (Option B) is shown by Salmonella, M.leprae and Coxiella species.

Adaptation to cytoplasmic replication (Option C) is shown by Listeria, Rickettsia and Francisella species.

questions.text:
A 20 year old girl presented to the OPD with complaints of night sweats, fever for 2 weeks. She has lost around 10 kgs since the past 6 months. Her vitals are as follows-

Her sputum is sent for diagnosis and an investigation called CBNAAT is performed.

Which of the following is/are true about CBNAAT?
1. It has the lowest turnaround time
2. It is a type of liquid media
3. It is based on real time PCR
4. It detects antibodies against M.TB
5. It is used for diagnosis of latent TB
6. It also detects rifampicin sensitivity
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic tool that detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance rapidly and with high sensitivity.
  • Statement 1 is correct: CBNAAT offers the lowest turnaround time (~2 hours), significantly faster than conventional culture-based methods.
  • Statement 3 is correct: CBNAAT works by real-time PCR technology to detect DNA of M. tuberculosis.
  • Statement 2 is incorrect: It is not a liquid culture method (like MGIT); instead, it uses a dry, self-contained cartridge.
  • Statement 4 is incorrect: It detects DNA of the bacilli, not antibodies.
  • Statement 5 is incorrect: It is not recommended for latent TB diagnosis; tests like the Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) or IGRA are used instead.
  • Statement 6 is correct: CBNAAT detects mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance.

choices.text: Presence of lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane
Presence of a thick peptidoglycan layer
Presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary reason Mycobacterium tuberculosis retains carbol fuchsin even after acid-alcohol decolourisation in Ziehl-Neelsen staining?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The acid-fastness of Mycobacterium tuberculosis is due to the high lipid content of its cell wall, specifically mycolic acids, which are long-chain β-hydroxy fatty acids.
  • These lipids give the cell wall a waxy consistency, making it impermeable to many dyes.
  • During Ziehl-Neelsen staining, carbol fuchsin is driven into the waxy cell wall by heating. Once stained, the dye is retained even after acid-alcohol decolourisation, which is the basis for classifying organisms like tuberculosis as acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Explanation of other options:

Presence of lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane (Option A): Found in Gram-negative bacteria, not in Mycobacterium. It does not contribute to acid-fastness.

Presence of thick peptidoglycan layer (Option B): Characteristic of Gram-positive bacteria, but not responsible for acid-fast staining.

Presence of capsule (Option D): May help in immune evasion, but does not affect staining properties or dye retention in Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

questions.text: You are examining the following slide of a patient's sputum who has evening rise of fever and cough for 1 month. After examining the slide, which of the following is the correct method to disinfect it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 5% phenol is the correct disinfectant used to inactivate infectious agents like Mycobacterium tuberculosis on sputum smear slides.
  • Slides prepared for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) detection contain potentially infectious bacilli and hence require disinfection to prevent laboratory-acquired infections.
  • Phenol acts by disrupting cell membranes and denaturing proteins, and a 5% solution is strong enough to achieve high-level disinfection for such high-risk specimens.

Explanation of other options:

1% phenol (Option B): This concentration is not sufficient to kill Mycobacterium tuberculosis, as it requires a higher phenol concentration for effective disinfection.

Povidone iodine (Option C): Though an effective antiseptic on skin and mucosa, it is not the agent of choice for disinfecting contaminated sputum slides due to limited efficacy against mycobacteria in the presence of organic material.

Chlorhexidine (Option D): Chlorhexidine is primarily active against gram-positive bacteria and has poor activity against mycobacteria, especially in high organic environments.

questions.text: Which strain is used for vaccination against Tuberculosis in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In India, the WHO recommended Danish 1331 strain of BCG is used.
  • BCG is available in lyophilised form and should be reconstituted before administration.
  • This is done by using normal saline as the diluent.
  • Distilled water is never used as it is an irritant.
  • Once reconstituted, it has to be administered within 1 hour
  • Administration of BCG:0.1 mL (0.1 mg TU) of BCG vaccine is administered above the insertion of the left deltoid by the intradermal route, using a 26-gauge tuberculin syringe.
  • BCG is directly given to the newborn soon after birth.
  • If not given at birth, it can be given later, up to 2 years.
  • The Edmonston Zagreb strain is used in the measles vaccine (Option A ruled out)
  • The Oka strain is used in the chickenpox vaccine (Option B ruled out).
  • SA 14-14-4 is used in the JE vaccine (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: A patient presented to the urology department with urinary frequency, dysuria, nocturia and abdominal pain. The patient is afebrile at the moment but complains of low-grade fever at night. Upon urinalysis, pus cells were found, but no bacterial agent was isolated. Imaging revealed a thimble bladder. Which specimen should be collected next for establishing a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features, along with sterile pyuria in urinalysis, raise a suspicion of genitourinary TB.
  • It is seen when tubercular bacilli are disseminated hematogenously.
  • It is diagnosed by collecting 3 early morning urine samples and processing them via culture in MGIT, LJ media or Genexpert.
  • Radiology may show strictures or perinephric abscesses.
  • It is treated well with ATT.
  • Urinary excretion of bacilli in renal tuberculosis is intermittent. Hence, it is advisable to test 3-6 first whole voided morning samples of urine.
  • Each sample is centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 30 minutes, and the sediment is used for culture after concentration.
  • Bladder biopsy is used for the diagnosis of Bladder cancer. (Option B ruled out)
  • CE-CT-(URETHRAL SWAB) is used to diagnose infections like gonococcal, chlamydia. (Option C ruled out)
  • HIV DNA PCR(CYSTOSCOPY SAMPLE) is used to detect the presence of HIV genetic material in a specific sample, which can help diagnose an infection. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
A 22 year old presented with headache, low grade fever, night sweats, anorexia, irritability and a positive Brudzinski sign. A Lumbar puncture revealed the following findings in the CSF.
Imaging reveals basal exudation. Given the patient's clinical presentation, the physician orders an acid fast staining of the CSF as well as cell counts. If the normal counts in the CSF are as follows, which of the following observations is incorrect about the CSF Findings in this case?
NORMAL CSF
Appearance - clear
CSF Pressure- 50-150 mm of water
Total WBC- 0-5 per mm3
Predominant cells- Lymphocytes
Glucose - 40-70mg%
Total proteins- 15-45 %
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The clinical vignette above is Tubercular meningitis.
  • In tuberculous meningitis, lymphocytes are the predominant cell type found in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), not neutrophils. Neutrophilic predominance is characteristic of acute pyogenic meningitis, such as that caused by Neisseria meningitidis or Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Tuberculous meningitis usually presents with:
    • High CSF protein: often >100 mg/dL (Option D)
    • Low CSF glucose: typically <40 mg/dL (Option B)
    • Lymphocytic predominance in WBCs (Option C)
    • Elevated CSF pressure
  • A classic image is the "cobweb clot" seen after standing, due to high fibrinogen.
  • Thus, a neutrophilic predominance is not expected and is incorrect for TB meningitis.
  • Imaging studies (CT and MRI) may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns. In more than half of the cases, evidence of old pulmonary lesions or a miliary pattern is found on chest X-ray.

questions.text: A patient with a one-week history of diarrhoea, accompanied by fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and lymphadenopathy, presents to the hospital. A biopsy of the lymph node reveals nontuberculous mycobacteria, and the patient has a CD4 count of 48cells/mm3. What would be the prophylaxis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In advanced HIV disease (CD4 < 50 cells/mm³), patients are at high risk for disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • While older guidelines recommended azithromycin monotherapy for prophylaxis, updated approaches favour dual therapy (typically a macrolide + ethambutol) for both prophylaxis and treatment, especially in confirmed cases or in high-risk individuals.
  • Prophylaxis is no longer routinely recommended unless the patient is not receiving effective ART, and there is a high endemicity or previous MAC colonisation.

Explanation of other options:

No prophylaxis (Option A): MAC infections are common in late-stage AIDS, and prophylaxis is advised for CD4 <50/mm³

Azithromycin (monotherapy) (Option B): Though azithromycin was used earlier for prophylaxis, monotherapy leads to resistance; combination therapy is now standard

Clarithromycin (monotherapy) (Option D): Same limitation as azithromycin; monotherapy is not sufficient due to the high risk of resistance

choices.text: Von Magnus phenomenon (immune response to vaccine strain adaptation)
Immunological tolerance (reduced immune response due to repeated exposure)
Viral interference (cross-protection between different viral strains)

questions.text: What immune response phenomenon is typically observed during the production of the influenza vaccine?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Immune response observed during the production influenza vaccine is Von Magnus phenomenon.
  • This refers to an immune response generated due to repeated passages of the influenza virus during vaccine production, especially in embryonated eggs.
  • The virus undergoes genetic changes that alter its immunogenicity and may lead to the formation of non-infective particles with high hemagglutinin titers.
  • These changes can influence vaccine effectiveness and strain selection.
    • Repeated passage results in immune adaptation and attenuation.
    • Resulting viral particles are often incomplete or non-replicative but highly immunogenic.
    • This phenomenon is important in the influenza vaccine strain

Explanation of other options:

Antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) (Option A): ADE occurs when antibodies facilitate viral entry into host cells, worsening the infection. This is well documented in dengue virus infections, but not seen in influenza vaccine production. ADE is unrelated to the attenuation or adaptation seen in vaccine strain development.

Immunological tolerance (Option C): This refers to the inactivation or suppression of the immune response due to repeated exposure to an antigen (e.g., self-antigens or persistent viral antigens). It is not involved in the influenza vaccine strain development process.

Viral interference (Option D): Viral interference is the phenomenon where infection by one virus inhibits infection by another, often due to interferon production. This concept is related to host antiviral defence, not to vaccine strain adaptation or production.
